summary:
The Security Council,

Reaffirming previous resolutions and presidential statements on Sudan, stresses full compliance. 
Reaffirming commitment to Sudan's sovereignty, unity, independence, and territorial integrity.

Recalling resolutions 1674 (2006), 1894 (2009) on civilian protection; 1612 (2005), 1882 (2009), 1998 (2011) on children and armed conflict; 1502 (2003) on humanitarian personnel; and 1325 (2000) on women, peace, and security.

Recalling the importance of ending impunity and ensuring justice for Darfur crimes.

Bearing in mind refugee and internally displaced persons' protection conventions.

Recalling reports on children and armed conflict in Sudan, including recommendations.

Expressing commitment to the African Union (AU)-UN Darfur peace process, hosted by Qatar.

Welcoming the 31 May 2011 All Darfur Stakeholders Conference (ADSC) and the 14 July Agreement.

Welcoming the Implementation Follow-up Committee (IFC) and Qatar's engagement.

Underlining the UN-AU partnership in maintaining peace and security in Africa.

Welcoming the report of the Secretary-General on UNAMID.

Stressing a rigorous approach to peacekeeping deployments.

Expressing deep concern at Darfur's deteriorating security situation.

Expressing concern at hostilities between the Government of Sudan and rebel groups. 
Calling on all parties to cease hostilities and facilitate humanitarian access.
Here is a concise summary of the Security Council document 2003 (2011):

The Security Council reiterates that there can be no military solution to the conflict in Darfur and that an inclusive political settlement is essential to re-establishing peace. The Council condemns all violations of international human rights and humanitarian law in Darfur and calls on all parties to comply with their obligations.

The Council extends the mandate of UNAMID for 12 months to 31 July 2012 and requests the Secretary-General to review the uniformed personnel required for UNAMID. The Council underlines the need for UNAMID to prioritize the protection of civilians, ensure safe humanitarian access, and maximize the use of its capabilities.

The Council demands that all parties engage in a permanent ceasefire and comprehensive peace settlement based on the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD). The Council recognizes the potential complementary role of a Darfur-based Political Process (DPP) led by the AU and the UN.
